summary: Major X: Early Appearance in Spider-Man/Deadpool #47 Is Blowing Up on eBay
title: Major X: Early Appearance in Spider-Man/Deadpool #47 Is Blowing Up on eBay
excerpt: Rob Liefeld's new character Major X made an appearance in Spider-Man/Deadpool #47, and now the issue is selling way above cover price on eBay.
description:
Major X, Rob Liefeld’s newest character, made an appearance in Spider-Man/Deadpool #47 before his new series launched. Now, the issue is creating a flurry of speculator activity on eBay.

On the popular auctioning site, the comic has sold from below the original cover price of $3.99 to over $40. Whether or not these issues will remain a longterm collector’s item or are a mere speculation a blip remains to be seen.

tags: i hate posting my writing but i just
that situation is so fucked up & its just not addressed???? at all??
summary:
dont tag as ship or i’ll kill you[[MORE]] 

she doesn’t look that much different than the day she died, in his universe. the...
body:
dont tag as ship or i’ll kill you

she doesn’t look that much different than the day she died, in his universe. the undercut was new- and, apparently, somehow miles’ fault?- but she had the same charming gap tooth grin and upturned button nose that gwen did. well, that’s probably because she was gwen.


“do you… need something?” she asked, reaching into aunt may’s cupboard as he leaned against the sink.


“uh, no, sorry.” he responded, averting his gaze, “you just-“


“i’m not your gwen.” she replied quietly, finally selecting a box of saltines (may had never had much of a snack selection). “and- you’re not my peter.”


“yeah.” peter agreed awkwardly, “uh. take care of yourself when you get back to your universe, alright?”


“what are you, my dad?” gwen joked good-naturedly in between saltines.


“god, no.” peter laughed, “no, in my universe we actually- uh, were dating for a little while, so that would be really weird.”


“really?” gwen raised an eyebrow in disbelief, before adding, “hey, what am i like in your universe? do i have, like, a job or…? sorry, that’s- a dumb way to ask-“
peter drummed his fingers on the sink, posture tense as he replied, “i don’t know.”


“bad breakup?”


“kind of,” peter responded, “you died.”


“oh.” gwen was quiet, withdrawing apologetically. “sorry about that?”


“‘s not your fault, kid.” it’s mine, his brain helpfully supplied. “junior year of high school. you look just like her.”


“do you wanna talk about it…?” she prompted, selecting another saltine. ah, the bottomless teenage appetite.


“that’s not fair to you- i shouldn’t be dumping my problems on you, you’re just-“
“just a kid.” she finished bitterly, rolling her eyes, “i fight supervillains, too, you know, i’m sure i can handle it. if you want to.”


“jesus, i forgot how fucked that was. why is new york always so reliant on teenage vigilantes?” peter laughed without humor, “kid, quick spiderman tip, get a good therapist before you end up like me.” divorced. disillusioned. kind of pathetic, honestly.


“i’ll… keep that in mind.”
body_abstract: dont tag as ship or i’ll kill you

summary: The fact that everyday of my life I wait around hoping either Taylor Swift or Tom Holland will post on Instagram means two...
body:
The fact that everyday of my life I wait around hoping either Taylor Swift or Tom Holland will post on Instagram means two things:

  1. I have no life🙃
  2. I might be reaching new and exciting levels of being an obsessive stan👍🏼

summary: “I had lots of time to get used to [the suit] because it was developed, really, on my body. They had a design which got very...
caption: “I had lots of time to get used to [the suit] because it was developed, really, on my body. They had a design which got very complicated. I mean at one point there was a backpack, with two lights that went on, the phosphorescent effects, but they said, ‘Wow, like this is too much. This is too much going on.’” - Willem Dafoe on playing Green Goblin 🎭

blog.name: dmydfilmreviews
blog.title: dMYDfilmreviews
blog.description:
d = don't
 M = maybe 
Y = Yes 
D = DEFINITELY

title: CAPTAIN AMERICA: THE FIRST AVENGER
body:
Captain America: The First Avenger is Marvel’s first great movie. Yeah, yeah, yeah, Iron Man is Robot Downey Jr: The Film and it started everything, Thor is Family Fortunes with trolls and shit. But Captain America is an old-fashioned, gung-ho period adventure, where a plucky underdog cracks Nazis in the jaw to a string-laden soundtrack and enough explosions for an explosion factory. And he’s a superhero. If Marvel’s ultimate goal is to make movies that are perfect to watch on a Saturday night with a beer and pizza, then The First Avenger is their first slam dunk.

 It starts, again, with the actors. This movie has an insane, perfect cast, from Tommy Lee Jones chewing up every scene he’s in to Hayley Atwell bursting out of nowhere as the smartest, toughest woman in the whole MCU (which has like five whole women now!). Stanley Tucci is adorable, Hugo Weaving and Toby Jones are the twin queens of camp-Nazi mountain and all the Howling Commandos are delightful gung-ho caricatures. But it’s Chris Evans who made himself a superstar, tackling the toughest role in the whole universe head on and coming out as the best Avenger. His Steve Rogers hasn’t got the snark of Stark or goofy awe of Thor but he makes something much harder work – a decent guy, someone who simply doesn’t like bullies and a straight-edge do-gooder. Yeah, it helps that he got arguably the best movies of the series built around him, but his Cap is so darned likeable and inspiring that within minutes you know he’s the only super worthy of leading the Avengers, and this is all down to Evans and Markus & McFeely, the writers who’d hone and guide him through Winter Soldiers, Civil and Infinity Wars and Endgame. They’re gonna kill him aren’t they. They’re gonna goddamn hell-ass kill him.

On an MCU nerd-level it’s astonishing how much they throw in here: the origins of the fabulous Agent Carter series, Bucky and Howard Stark, the Tesseract and the Skull starring at the World Tree, about to be condemned to an eternity beyond his tiny hate. The movie in isolation’s almost perfect, really; it whips along, the action’s satisfying and old-school, the period trappings are fantastic. But compared to the rest of the MCU it shares an essential quality with the first Avengers, a ‘comic-booky’ style that was dolloped with realism from Phase 2 onwards. It’s old-school comics made flesh, a Saturday matinee spectacular that also serves as the zero-point for so much of the MCU’s overarching narrative.

But it wouldn’t be any of this without heart. That’s the secret. From Steve jumping on the fake grenade to dying Erskine tapping his chest, from losing his best friend off the side of a speeding train to the final, heartbreaking ‘I had a date’, this is a straight-forward, full-hearted movie, the kind they don’t make anymore except when they do. It’s fucking great. And Steve and Bucky are gay as hell.

reblog.comment:

It’s old-school comics made flesh, a Saturday matinee spectacular that also serves as the zero-point for so much of the MCU’s overarching narrative.

But it wouldn’t be any of this without heart. That’s the secret. From Steve jumping on the fake grenade to dying Erskine tapping his chest, from losing his best friend off the side of a speeding train to the final, heartbreaking ‘I had a date’, this is a straight-forward, full-hearted movie, the kind they don’t make anymore except when they do. It’s fucking great. And Steve and Bucky are gay as hell.

trail.content_raw:
Captain America: The First Avenger is Marvel’s first great movie. Yeah, yeah, yeah, Iron Man is Robot Downey Jr: The Film and it started everything, Thor is Family Fortunes with trolls and shit. But Captain America is an old-fashioned, gung-ho period adventure, where a plucky underdog cracks Nazis in the jaw to a string-laden soundtrack and enough explosions for an explosion factory. And he’s a superhero. If Marvel’s ultimate goal is to make movies that are perfect to watch on a Saturday night with a beer and pizza, then The First Avenger is their first slam dunk.

 It starts, again, with the actors. This movie has an insane, perfect cast, from Tommy Lee Jones chewing up every scene he’s in to Hayley Atwell bursting out of nowhere as the smartest, toughest woman in the whole MCU (which has like five whole women now!). Stanley Tucci is adorable, Hugo Weaving and Toby Jones are the twin queens of camp-Nazi mountain and all the Howling Commandos are delightful gung-ho caricatures. But it’s Chris Evans who made himself a superstar, tackling the toughest role in the whole universe head on and coming out as the best Avenger. His Steve Rogers hasn’t got the snark of Stark or goofy awe of Thor but he makes something much harder work – a decent guy, someone who simply doesn’t like bullies and a straight-edge do-gooder. Yeah, it helps that he got arguably the best movies of the series built around him, but his Cap is so darned likeable and inspiring that within minutes you know he’s the only super worthy of leading the Avengers, and this is all down to Evans and Markus & McFeely, the writers who’d hone and guide him through Winter Soldiers, Civil and Infinity Wars and Endgame. They’re gonna kill him aren’t they. They’re gonna goddamn hell-ass kill him.

On an MCU nerd-level it’s astonishing how much they throw in here: the origins of the fabulous Agent Carter series, Bucky and Howard Stark, the Tesseract and the Skull starring at the World Tree, about to be condemned to an eternity beyond his tiny hate. The movie in isolation’s almost perfect, really; it whips along, the action’s satisfying and old-school, the period trappings are fantastic. But compared to the rest of the MCU it shares an essential quality with the first Avengers, a ‘comic-booky’ style that was dolloped with realism from Phase 2 onwards. It’s old-school comics made flesh, a Saturday matinee spectacular that also serves as the zero-point for so much of the MCU’s overarching narrative.

But it wouldn’t be any of this without heart. That’s the secret. From Steve jumping on the fake grenade to dying Erskine tapping his chest, from losing his best friend off the side of a speeding train to the final, heartbreaking ‘I had a date’, this is a straight-forward, full-hearted movie, the kind they don’t make anymore except when they do. It’s fucking great. And Steve and Bucky are gay as hell.
trail.content:
Captain America: The First Avenger is Marvel’s first great movie. Yeah, yeah, yeah, Iron Man is Robot Downey Jr: The Film and it started everything, Thor is Family Fortunes with trolls and shit. But Captain America is an old-fashioned, gung-ho period adventure, where a plucky underdog cracks Nazis in the jaw to a string-laden soundtrack and enough explosions for an explosion factory. And he’s a superhero. If Marvel’s ultimate goal is to make movies that are perfect to watch on a Saturday night with a beer and pizza, then The First Avenger is their first slam dunk.

 It starts, again, with the actors. This movie has an insane, perfect cast, from Tommy Lee Jones chewing up every scene he’s in to Hayley Atwell bursting out of nowhere as the smartest, toughest woman in the whole MCU (which has like five whole women now!). Stanley Tucci is adorable, Hugo Weaving and Toby Jones are the twin queens of camp-Nazi mountain and all the Howling Commandos are delightful gung-ho caricatures. But it’s Chris Evans who made himself a superstar, tackling the toughest role in the whole universe head on and coming out as the best Avenger. His Steve Rogers hasn’t got the snark of Stark or goofy awe of Thor but he makes something much harder work – a decent guy, someone who simply doesn’t like bullies and a straight-edge do-gooder. Yeah, it helps that he got arguably the best movies of the series built around him, but his Cap is so darned likeable and inspiring that within minutes you know he’s the only super worthy of leading the Avengers, and this is all down to Evans and Markus & McFeely, the writers who’d hone and guide him through Winter Soldiers, Civil and Infinity Wars and Endgame. They’re gonna kill him aren’t they. They’re gonna goddamn hell-ass kill him.

On an MCU nerd-level it’s astonishing how much they throw in here: the origins of the fabulous Agent Carter series, Bucky and Howard Stark, the Tesseract and the Skull starring at the World Tree, about to be condemned to an eternity beyond his tiny hate. The movie in isolation’s almost perfect, really; it whips along, the action’s satisfying and old-school, the period trappings are fantastic. But compared to the rest of the MCU it shares an essential quality with the first Avengers, a ‘comic-booky’ style that was dolloped with realism from Phase 2 onwards. It’s old-school comics made flesh, a Saturday matinee spectacular that also serves as the zero-point for so much of the MCU’s overarching narrative.

But it wouldn’t be any of this without heart. That’s the secret. From Steve jumping on the fake grenade to dying Erskine tapping his chest, from losing his best friend off the side of a speeding train to the final, heartbreaking ‘I had a date’, this is a straight-forward, full-hearted movie, the kind they don’t make anymore except when they do. It’s fucking great. And Steve and Bucky are gay as hell.

body: peter’s probably sat in the soulstone thinking about everything he said to tony before he died and realising how much guilt that must have put on him. he starts taking after his mentor a bit more after that thought.
